snippet: Private equity firms have used sophisticated but indirect political maneuvering with state and local entities to smooth the way for growth and revenue....
abstract: Investigation by New York Times has discovered Fortress Investment Group and other private equity firms have greatly expanded their political influence since 2008 financial crisis, in large part due to sophisticated maneuvering both at state and federal level; even as private equity has had pervasive impact on most Americans' lives, few are aware of it as industry indirectly engages with regulators and lawmakers through companies owned by private equity firms (Series: Bottom Line Nation).

byline.original: By BEN PROTESS, JESSICA SILVER-GREENBERG and RACHEL ABRAMS
byline.contributor: Ben Protess reported from Phoenix and Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Rachel Abrams reported from New York. Ron Nixon, Peter Eavis and Alain Delaquérière contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: Private equity firms have used sophisticated but indirect political maneuvering with state and local entities to smooth the way for growth and revenue.

headline.print_headline: How Private Equity Firms Quietly Cash In on Political Capital
headline.main: How Private Equity Found Power and Profit in State Capitols
